comments.commentBody:
As long as Trump is willing to essentially gut NATO, to leave the Middle East stage to Putin, to allow Putin;s extension of his Greater Russia realm, I think Trump and Putin can indeed be buddies.

There is one aspect of Trump living in the White House I find interesting. He seems willing to help accomplishing the GOP dream of upsetting the Federal apple cart up to this point but given that he has no basic belief and no principle in term of governance the consequence of his action and inaction is unpredictable. So as long as he does not blow up the world by playing with the nuclear code maybe the world does indeed need some dosage of his unpredictable "medicine".

As the Taoist said: A calamity is what a blessing leans on, and hidden in a blessing is a calamity". So is Trump living a White House a blessing or a calamity? We will find out, I suspect, in two years assuming he does not blow up the world by then.

I submit that an underlying problem causing media deficit attention arises from the great number of outlets working feverishly to fill up the 24/7 all news all the time cycle. Media and their editors and executives are under pressure to produce content whether it's a cable news network or a news oriented website. It's clear that such outlets abhor a vacuum and the filler provided by a circus act like Trump is easy and plentiful. A windfall for Les Moonves and plenty of air time provided by CNN's decision to broadcast entire incoherent speeches of the President -Elect.

The 24/7 news cycle is the American rat race writ large. A pause, an evaluation of what is reported is sorely needed. A pundit recently suggested that every Trump tweet not be reported on unless truly newsworthy. That would be a start. Like any machine or engine, if the 24/7 pressure to fill a void does not dial back , the breakdown of 2016 will continue unabated.

Good point. However, it is more than just the need to fill all that air time. It is the need to fill it cheaply. The more there is to fill, the less can be spent on each minute of content filling it.

They could fill it with actual reporting. Real reporting is expensive, and real reporters with knowledge are more expensive.

It is cheaper and faster to fill it as a megaphone for whoever feeds young cheap hires with press releases or does something flashy or outrageous in front of a camera.

Budgets were cut as time filled increased. Reporting bureaux closed and experienced reporters fired even as more "reports" came in. Editors who might question and demand were the first to go.

Agree. The more air time to fill, less quality of news. The curse of cable.
But if govt tries to control the negative influence of advances in technology---such as social media or even 24/7 cable TV news---accusations of censorship will fly. This is how corporations profit from our founding ideals of press freedom. And now fake news sites on the web profit from advertising.
Can you just hear drumpf scream at media if they don't report his every tweet---'breaking news'?

A counter to commercial media would be well funded public media---it was created for that---but PBS/NPR has to go to corporate sponsors, as congress underfunds it.

Combine all this with the destructive effects of Bill Clinton's repealing laws that had prevented media monopolies Now a few huge news conglomerates control what topics media reports, increasing profits, increasing campaign donations, cleaning up big money from campaign ads. We get the atrocious politics and coverage of 2016, with 2 of the most disliked candidates ever.
Maybe drumpf's win shouldn't be so shocking.

Only elected govts can step in to regulate in the public interest, but govt has a bad reputation since the Gop dominance, and the need of Dems for billions in private campaign donations. A vicious cycle.
Cost America influence and prestige? How many lives were saved? That is the only thing that matters.
Just wait. We'v seen this picture before.

Well, Welcome, how many lives were saved? Can you give us a number, just a ball park number? On the other hand, The Editors tell us that 400,000 lives have been LOST with no reasonable end in sight. 400,000+ matters.

The 'Syrian solution' seems more about purging 'undesirables' than about saving lives. This is the mark of the despots and tyrants that are tearing the country apart. It is also the reason why Obama didn't just 'jump in'.

It is notable that Trump (along with a majority of his Republican counterparts) seem to see clear merit in despotism that 'purges undesirables' that threaten the absolute power necessary to 'corner the market' on mammon.

A few nights ago, I again watched the Maysles' brothers documentary "Grey Gardens" about the Beale mother and daughter, Edith and little Edie. Although their living conditions were so tragic, the dynamic between that mother and daughter somehow came to mind when I saw previews of the upcoming Reynolds/Fisher film. Everything was a little frenetic with the Beales, with each woman sometimes irritated by the other but still very much needing the connection, something many of us daughters can relate to.

I am so sorry for Carrie's daughter and brother. I hope they take comfort from the outpouring of affection from the public.

Let's get the facts straight.

Bill Clinton didn't abolish the Fairness Doctrine. It was abolished under Reagan at the instigation of Lewis Powell a decade earlier. (Google "Powell memorandum.") For his reengineering of America to be taken over by the American right, Powell was rewarded with the Supreme Court. Corporate America asked Powell how to squash the American left. He told them and corporate America made it happen. Just as corporate America today dictates the "news" agenda of the country.

To see the truth of that, one need only watch network television coverage of election night. The anchors were positively bemused by the result and anybody sitting with them who wanted to take it remotely seriously was quickly shut up. Why? Because contrary to the 40-year campaign by the American right, television "journalists" aren't liberals. Most couldn't care less who's president. As members of the political and economic elite, it doesn't affect their lives a bit. (If they care at all, they like Republicans. Witness their coverage of Hillary Clinton.) What broadcast "journalists" care most about is keeping their corporate bosses happy and keeping seven-figure paychecks. (Witness CBS's abandonment of Dan Rather when the story he reported was, contrary to conventional wisdom, reported accurately.) I speak as someone who once lived inside the media elite. If we're counting on American "journalism" to save us from fascism, we're cooked.

It's only "fearmongering" if the threat isn't real.

I hope I'm right, that Trump won't cook the planet beyond all hope, won't sell out those who will need Medicare and Social Security and the sort of help the ACA offered, imperfectly. I hope his tenure won't further embolden the voices of bigotry and racism the United States has had to beat back for its entire history. But I am afraid. And I think you should be too.
May his tenure (their tenure, really) be short! That's my wish for 2017.

and Elke
Not yet 2017 here.
I'll OWN UP TO it- am not as SMART as I thought. Since my AcrossLite printed out circles ( no bars), I had to recheck for a missed notepad maybe, but nothing. Only found "aisles" at xwordinfo.
Pity about that, because many of the clues were GREAT.
Here the LOCAL RAINGOD took REFUGE and sent out his frozen colleague, resulting in a lot of snow. The AVALANCHE centre has issued its warnings.
Wondering whether YODELs can trigger AVALANCHEs, but am not offering to TEST that.
TV on in background- it's very noisy in NYCity.
HNY to all.

In just these few comments I've read more "coverage" of global warming, all contributed by non-journalists, than I recall reading, hearing, or seeing "coverage" by the MSM in the entire presidential election campaign.
There are no ad dollars garnered here. And it's probably not meaningful to Mr Kristof's readership numbers. It's not likely any Trump supporters will be enlightened on this issue here...

Meanwhile, for over 1 year our military generals have been calling global warming a major national security risk. So now I wonder, will their position on global warming likely clash with Trump's views, prompting Trump to dismiss the generals concerns in similar fashion as he's dissed the CIA and FBI over the Russian election hacking issue?
@dan Stackhouse:   Unbelievably astute comment! Thank you, you've nailed it in your parable-like way.
It's not fear-mongering if it's actually true. The Russians actually came! They may have been a determining factor in the election of Trump.

As a former journalism student who was an editor on the daily university paper at a public institution of 25,000 in the Midwest, I have to disagree that we were molded in the likeness of left-wing faculty.

My experience and observation is that my journalism peers veer left of center due to what we see and report working on the paper. Getting the sheepskin is important, but secondary to building a clipbook of stories garnered from real-world reporting. The real world isn't pretty, nor is it fair.

It's not so much media's failure as other pols. For example, the Dem party can start taking control of some of the narrative by having one or more fire brands or the next big things make statements via Soc Media that bring attention to subjects not being discussed or a completely unexpected take on something being discussed rather than just responding to something other parties or the media says. Better yet, add Trump's name to the statement so it gets his attention and gets him talking about or defending the opposite.

What seems to me to be missing here is a hard look at media consumers and voters. The loss of analysis and depth of reporting has been happening for decades, and most Americans seem quite willing to accept it. I really hope the news media do try to do a better job, but what if they do and they start losing money by it?

On a related note, I think the media's failure to push voters they interviewed has contributed to this mess. I heard endless interviews with Trump supporters who were not challenged about Trump's lies, pandering to racism, or complete lack of understanding of issues. I believe this contributed to the idea that he is somehow acceptable.

I don't know how large your income, and I have no idea of what your net worth is, but I know for sure that in both of these categories yours are exponentially greater than mine. In other words, you are one of those rich people you pillory, and every bit as greedy, I'm sure.

But let's cut to the chase--taxes! You like taxing the rich because you collect a princely (by my standards) sum of money from taxes, indirectly, perhaps, in your salary from a university that gets lots of taxpayers' money from the government, and directly when you obtain a government grant for some worthy--in you opinion--project or study.

"A heavy, progressive income tax," as recommended by Karl Marx in his communist manifesto, "by means of despotic inroads on the rights of property," is what we now have in America. The federal, individual income tax "brackets" range from 10% on incomes of less than $13,250, to 39.6% for incomes above $441,000. Obviously, an across-the-board tax reduction of say 10% will yield a much greater dollar reduction for the person in the highest income bracket than someone in the lowest brackets. Unless one's objective is to punish the rich taxpayer even more than he already is, the across-the-board cut looks eminently fair. The rich guy earning $441,000 will still be paying 131 times more money in taxes than the poor gal earning $13,250. 131 times more! I would think Marx would be satisfied if not Professor Krugman.
I believe that your arithmetic is in error.  Better take the problem to a competent tax consultant.

Yet as we saw in 2012, Mr. Romney paid taxes to the gavernment at a lower _rate_ on his income than did the starting office assistants (aka secretaries) in his employ.  So much for punishing the rich!

Ned: "In other words, you are one of those rich people you pillory, and every bit as greedy, I'm sure."

Of course you are...

Good point. However, it is more than just the need to fill all that air time. It is the need to fill it cheaply. The more there is to fill, the less can be spent on each minute of content filling it.

They could fill it with actual reporting. Real reporting is expensive, and real reporters with knowledge are more expensive.

It is cheaper and faster to fill it as a megaphone for whoever feeds young cheap hires with press releases or does something flashy or outrageous in front of a camera.

Budgets were cut as time filled increased. Reporting bureaux closed and experienced reporters fired even as more "reports" came in. Editors who might question and demand were the first to go.

One place to look is television news.  How many days and nights did they runs stories labeled "Email Scandal" only to say nothing substantive or in any related to any sort of "scandal?"  They nustbparroted whatever Trump and his minions said.  The lazy coverage of this issue dominated the final weeks of the campaign.   Nor did they do anything to counter the endless baseless accusations about Benghazi and every other weak accusation hurled at Secretary  Clinton. All they did was amplify the character assassinations. Whatever happened to investigating and reporting news instead of just replay sound bites with no substance behind these blurbs. No investigations. No pointing out the falsehoods and baseless accusations. Mere parroting. Shame.

Like recovering the economy, restoring respect to the United States, doing what he can to promote and protect the environment? As opposed to hate crimes and injustice?

Wrong, wrong, and wrong. The unified obstruction of Republicans was immoral and wrong. And blaming victims is wrong.

Unfortunately, you, along with the rest of us, are going to experience a world radically changed for the worse because of the ascension of the dumpster fire of vanity and kleptocrat enabler Trump.

There were multiple nefarious factors that led to Trumps alleged victory. But
all the Media attention is the real 800 pound gorilla that got Trump elected.

Every news site seem to have Trump in at least half the political news. I guess Trump's absurd stamements and outrageous tweet's made for entertaining gee whiz reporting. Suddenly serious politicians like Hilary and Bernie were being compared with a tweeting hypersensitive political newbie.

The media's insistence on false equivalences played a big part in Trump "victory". Where's somebody like Walter Cronkite these days?

As a cemetery enthusiast who likes to find the final resting places of people generally worthy of admiration, I hope Todd selects a final resting place that is in good taste, and will accommodate fans who wish to pay their respects.

No crypts deep in the non public areas of Forest Lawn. A nice grave site at Westwood Village Cemetery would be ideal.

"Godsend'? In what way is Trump doing the Lords work? I think you are wrong in your support of the conservatives. They are gearing up to cut Medicare and the ACA. There will be nothing to replace those programs. I work in healthcare.  It won’t  long before insurance becomes un-affordable and they are kicking women with breast cancer out of their plans. The poor and the elderly will be made to go without so that the wealthy can have more tax cuts. How do you reconcile that with your Christian background? I worry about my community and family. Every dollar removed from someone poor, retired or working class, makes my town poorer. Why should anyone be happy about that? Trump is an empty vessel and he is no Christian. He will go along with the cuts, because there will be tax cuts for the wealthy like him to be gained. At what point will you say enough?

"At what point will you say enough?" Perhaps when there are people lying in the streets, sick and dying and homeless? Maybe not even then.

Yes, every dollar taken away from the poor to go into the coffers of the rich will mean that those who have been living hand-to-mouth, trying to feed their children and keep even a leaky roof over their heads will find it hard to keep up.

2016 was a dreadful year. 2017 with the Orange Puff doesn't bode well for those of us who truly count on every penny of our Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid. Those three programs have kept poor people off the streets and in some kind of decent situation. But we know that Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell are drooling, just waiting to pounce on those blessed programs, to cut them down to nothing and continue to give to the rich who do nothing with their money but throw it in an off-shore bank. Poor people spend the little bit of money they have, helping to keep the economy alive.

It's time to organize, not time to celebrate. This little jingle keeps coming to me, "Stand Up, Sign Up, Don't Pay Your Taxes". I do plan on organizing. And fighting the Orange Puff and Vampire Boy Ryan and Turtle McConnell with every breath I have.

E,
If you can get the repubs to engineer health insurance that actually covers healthcare at the costs you want, I'll be with you all the way. But you know better than that. The Republicans will get rid of the ACA and the wealthy will walk off with their tax cuts.

It's called "insurance"--look it up ebmem. Basically, we pool our resources so that nobody has to do without. Your second paragraph sets up the multimillionaire straw man and you continue the falsehood from there. C'mmon!
Don't forget: Trump agreed to release his income tax returns.

Trump is a dangerous vengeful conscienceless shallow ego-obsessed fool, bent on selling our country for thirty pieces of silver, without regret and without knowledge of the destruction he plans.

I doubt there is much Obama can do to prevent the coming dangerous degradation of American, which is about to be made small and mean and broken.

God help us all (and I'm an atheist).

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
I applaud your political trainers for heaping every bit of anger & fear they had right into your heart. And you were created to be an independent, reasonable person able to deal rationally with real issues.
You seriously need to change your reading sources for news. Try places that actually make money in the media biz.
We could tell long ago that your parting admission was the truth.

Susan, Susan....

Relax, babe.
Trump "knows things that other people don't know".
We're all good here.

Be careful what you wish for. Look at Trump's behavior and history. Obama is dignified, kind, and wise, thinks hard and studies before acting. Despite the continuing scandal of unified Republican obstruction he is a gentleman.

Trump is a spoiled brat with a history of taking advantage of people and making extravagant claims that are not backed up by his actions.

"his mode is recklessness, a self-admiring belief that unpredictability is the path to national salvation."

"every day brings at least one fresh outrage: the appointment of a national-security adviser whose temperament resembles those of the unhinged generals in “Dr. Strangelove”; a keeper of the environment who denies the science of climate change; a chief strategist and senior counselor who ran a Web site laced with racist poison and bogus “news”; an Attorney General who regards the Voting Rights Act as “intrusive” and once referred to a subordinate as “boy.”

"contrary to Trump’s vow to “drain the swamp,” comprise ... a new, improved version of the swamp, in which the super-wealthy and the oil and gas industries are vested with singular authority. ... a background of brewing scandals, myriad conflicts of interest, the gleeful humiliation of longstanding foes, and a President-elect who refuses to show even a measure of curiosity about the possibility that Russian intelligence agencies meddled in a national election." http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/trump_daily_bankruptcy_israel_am...
One of the best tributes ever. You captured that sparkling essence loved by millions. Thank you!

WhatTheFact: Try this: http://www.nytimes.com/section/science/earth

The NYT is making a valiant effort, but they are stuck with the market. Justin Gillis is extraordinary, and there are half a dozen other good reporters. They do sometimes veer into "balanced" coverage which is biased by nature, since a 97:3 issue covered 50:50 is giving too much to the dissenters and too little to the vast majority of expert opinion.

But people seem to hate experts: never mind that their health, their houses, their computers, and most of what they depend on requires expertise.

Here's a simple statement about the scientific/physics obvious, known since the 1800s, and clear as day since the 1980s:

We are accumulating heat-trapping greenhouse gases in our atmosphere, which are increasing the energy (heat) in the system (global warming) which is disrupting our planetary circulation (climate change).

There is also more water vapor which means floods and snowstorms are bigger.

Those 30 pieces of silver: make the US safe for kleptocrats.

Admiring dictators.

Hate crimes on the rise.

Promoting international conflicts.
